title: Megavitamin therapy - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: scientific |[Alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) Megavitamin therapy is the use of large doses of [vitamins](/wiki/Vitamin), often many times greater than the [recommended dietary allowance](/wiki/Recommended_dietary_allowance) (RDA) in the attempt to prevent or treat [diseases](/wiki/Disease). Megavitamin therapy is typically used in [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine) by practitioners who call their approach [orthomolecular medicine](/wiki/Orthomolecular_medicine). [[1]](#cite_note-1) Vitamins are useful in preventing and treating illnesses specifically associated with dietary vitamin shortfalls, but the conclusions of medical research are that the broad claims of disease treatment by advocates of megavitamin therapy are unsubstantiated by the available evidence. [[2]](#cite_note-isbn1-55009-213-8-2) [[3]](#cite_note-References1990-3) It is generally accepted that doses of any vitamin greatly in excess of nutritional requirements will result either in toxicity (vitamins A and D) or in the excess simply being metabolised; thus evidence in favour of vitamin supplementation supports only doses in the normal range. [[4]](#cite_note-4) [[5]](#cite_note-5) [[6]](#cite_note-6) Critics have described some aspects of [food faddism](/wiki/Food_faddism) Research on nutrient supplementation in general suggests that some nutritional supplements might be beneficial, and that others might be harmful; [[10]](#cite_note-10) [[11]](#cite_note-11) [[12]](#cite_note-12) several specific nutritional therapies are associated with an increased likelihood of the condition they are meant to prevent. [[13]](#cite_note-AmJEpidem2009-13) Multivitamin vs megavitamin[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=1)] Megavitamin therapy must be distinguished from the usual "vitamin supplementation" approach of traditional multivitamin pills. Megavitamin doses are far higher than the levels of vitamins ordinarily available through western diets. A study of 161,000 individuals (post-menopausal women) provided, in the words of the authors, "convincing evidence that multivitamin use has little or no influence on the risk of common cancers, cardiovascular disease, or total mortality in postmenopausal women". [[14]](#cite_note-WHI-14) History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=2)] In the 1930s and 1940s, some scientific and clinical evidence suggested that there might be beneficial uses of vitamins C, E, and niacin in large doses. Beginning in the 1930s in [Canada](/wiki/Canada), a megadose vitamin E therapy for cardiovascular and circulatory complaints was developed by [Evan Shute](/wiki/Evan_Shute) and colleagues, named the "Shute protocol". [[15]](#cite_note-pmid18911314-15) Tentative experiments in the 1930s by [Claus W. Jungeblut](/wiki/Claus_W._Jungeblut) [[16]](#cite_note-16) with larger doses of vitamin C led to Frederick Klenner's development of [megadose](/wiki/Vitamin_C_megadosage) intravenous vitamin C treatments for polio and other viruses in the 1940s. [[17]](#cite_note-pmid18147027-17) William Kaufman published articles in the 1940s that detailed his treatment of arthritis with frequent, high doses of niacinamide. [[18]](#cite_note-pmid13060032-18) Rudolf Altschul and [Abram Hoffer](/wiki/Abram_Hoffer) applied large doses of the immediate release form of [niacin](/wiki/Niacin_(nutrient)) (Vitamin B3) to treat [hypercholesterolemia](/wiki/Hypercholesterolemia). [[19]](#cite_note-19) [[20]](#cite_note-pmid13792994-20) In a 1956 publication entitled Biochemical Individuality, [Roger J. Williams](/wiki/Roger_J._Williams) introduced concepts for individualized megavitamins and nutrients. [[21]](#cite_note-isbn0-87983-893-0-21) Megavitamin therapies were also publicly advocated by [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling) in the late 1960s. [[22]](#cite_note-isbn0-399-50764-7-22) Usage as therapy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=3)] Although megavitamin therapies still largely remain outside of the structure of [evidence-based medicine](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine), they are increasingly used by patients, with or without the approval of their treating physicians, often after recommendations by practitioners of orthomolecular and [naturopathic medicine](/wiki/Naturopathic_medicine). [[23]](#cite_note-pmid10893280-23) The proposed efficacy of various megavitamin therapies to reduce cancer risk has been contradicted by results of one clinical trial. [[24]](#cite_note-pmid19116389-24) Vitamin C[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=4)] The US [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance) for [vitamin C](/wiki/Vitamin_C) for adult women is 76 mg/day and for adult men 90 mg/day. Although [Linus Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling) was known for highly respectable research in chemistry and biochemistry, he was also known for promoting the consumption of vitamin C in large doses. [[25]](#cite_note-25) Although he claimed and stood firm in his claim that consuming over 1,000 mg is helpful for one's immune system when fighting a head cold, the results of empirical research do not align with this view. A meta-analysis concluded that supplementary vitamin C significantly lowered serum [uric acid](/wiki/Uric_acid), considered a risk factor for [gout](/wiki/Gout). [[26]](#cite_note-26) One population study reported an inverse correlation between dietary vitamin C and risk of gout. [[27]](#cite_note-27) A review of clinical trials in the treatment of colds with small and large doses of Vitamin C has established that there is no evidence that it decreases the incidence of [common colds](/wiki/Common_cold). [[28]](#cite_note-28) After 33 years of research, it is still not established whether vitamin C can be used as a treatment for cancer. [[29]](#cite_note-29) Vitamin E[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=5)] The US [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance) for [vitamin E](/wiki/Vitamin_E) for adult women and men is 15 mg/day. The US Food and Nutrition Board set a [tolerable upper intake level (UL)](/wiki/Tolerable_upper_intake_levels) at 1,000 mg (1,500 IU) per day derived from animal models that demonstrated bleeding at high doses. [[30]](#cite_note-DRItext-30) In the US, the popularity for vitamin E as a dietary supplement-popular doses 400, 800 and 1000 IU/day-peaked around 2000. Declines in usage were attributed to publications of studies that showed either no benefits or negative consequences from vitamin E supplements. [[31]](#cite_note-31) One meta-analysis showed no association between vitamin E supplementation and cardiovascular events (nonfatal stroke or myocardial infarction) or cardiovascular mortality. [[32]](#cite_note-32) Another meta-analysis concluded vitamin E increased [edit](/w/index.php?title=Megavitamin_therapy&action=edit§ion=6)] The US [Recommended Dietary Allowance](/wiki/Recommended_Dietary_Allowance) for [niacin](/wiki/Niacin_(nutrient)) for adult women is 14 mg/day and for adult men 16 mg/day. Niacin is available as a prescription product, either immediate release (500 mg tablets; prescribed up to 3,000 mg/day) or extended release (500 and 1,000 mg tablets; prescribed up to 2,000 mg/day). In the US, niacin is also available as a [dietary supplement](/wiki/Dietary_supplement) at 500 to 1,000 mg/tablet. Niacin has sometimes been used in combination with other [lipid-lowering medications](/wiki/Lipid-lowering_medication). [[34]](#cite_note-TabletLabel-34) Systematic reviews found no effect of niacin on [cardiovascular disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease) or death, in spite of raising [high-density lipoprotein](/wiki/High-density_lipoprotein) (HDL) cholesterol.
